Notes brought up to current standards, added process on demand parts, published minimal finding aid.
Published version of the finding aid containing Plath letters and recently processed portions of 1999 accession
published version of finding aid including most recently reviewed boxes

did.abstract: Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse was a psychiatrist, theologian, and ordained Episcopal priest known for being poet Syvia Plath's psychiatrist, and for her theological publications related to homosexuality, sex, and women in the Christian church. This collection contains materials reflecting both her personal and professional lives, most of it from about 1970 and later. The collection contains a small amount of materials related to Sylvia Plath, which have been put in separate series for ease of access and reference.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series 1, 2, and 4 of this collection are open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.
Effective September 6, 2018, Series 3 of this collection is also open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

Series 5, which currently contains the bulk of this collection, must be thoroughly reviewed by an archivist for confidential patient, ministerial, and student information prior to access. This series is being processed on demand; please contact Smith College Special Collections to request that a portion be processed for your use.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse began donating her papers to the Sophia Smith Collection in 1999. This collection is comprised of the following accessions received from Barnhouse, her estate, her family, and Harriet Rosenstein in 1999-2008 and 2018: 99S-14, 00S-35, 01S-21, 2017S-006, 2018-S-0024.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged in five series: the first contains a small trove of letters from Barnhouse's parents that she kept in a special box throughout her life and which were sent to the archives in 2008; the second contains all known Sylvia Plath-related files in the collection, which have been separated for ease of access and reference; the third contains 14 letters from Sylvia Plath to Ruth Beuscher (later Ruth Barnhouse) obtained from Harriet Rosenstein; the fourt contains materials from Barnhouse's papers that have been thoroughly screened for confidential information and are open for use; the fifth contains all unprocessed materials which must be reviewed for confidential patient and pastoral information prior to access. Materials within the fifth series are arranged into subseries by the accession with which they were received.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse was a Jungian psychiatrist, theologian, and ordained Episcopal priest known for being poet Sylvia Plath's psychiatrist, and for her theological publications and teachings related to homosexuality, sex, and women in the Christian church.

Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse was born in France in 1923. She was schooled in France and Germany before World War II. She received her B.A. from Barnard College, M.D. from Columbia University, and Th.M. from the Weston College School of Theology (Jesuit). She began private practice as a psychiatrist in 1956. As an attending staff psychiatrist at McLean Hospital, she served as psychiatrist to poet Sylvia Plath. She was also a clinical assistant in psychology at Harvard University.

Barnhouse moved to Washington, D.C. in 1978 and worked as adjunct professor of pastoral theology at the Virginia Theological Seminary. From 1980-1989, she was on the faculty of Dallas's Southern Methodist University as professor of psychiatry and pastoral care at the Perkins School of Theology. Also in 1980, she was ordained a priest in the Episcopal Church.

In 1991, she began working as a consultant to the human resources department of a major Dallas corporation. She was a co-founder of the Dallas chapter of the Physicians for Social Responsibility. She was the president of Peacemakers, Inc., which put on an international women's conference entitled "Global Peace...from Vision to Reality" in 1988. She was also president of the Isthmus Institute, an organization concerned with the interactions between scientific and religious approaches to reality. She was an assistant editor of the Anglican Theological Review and a past president of the Conference of Anglican Theologians. She served on the joint commission on health and human affairs of the general convention of the Episcopal Church. She was the first woman and first lay person to be a fellow of the College of Preachers in Washington, D.C. and she served on its council as chair of the program and policy committee for six years.

She frequently gave lectures, workshops, and radio-tv interviews acorss the country for psychiatric professional societies, mental health centers, pastors'schools, clergy and lay retreats, and civic groups. She is author of numerous publications including Homosexuality: A symbolic confusion (1977), Identity(1987), Clergy and the Sexual Revolution(1987), Sex and War (1991), A Woman's Identity (1994), and co-editor of Female: Christian Approaches to Sexuality.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse papers, Sophia Smith Collection, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Massachusetts.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The materials in Series 4 have been thoroughly reviewed for confidential patient, pastoral, and student records. A detailed note about that work is attached to the series description.

The materials in Series 5 have not been processed, in the sense that archival appraisal, arrangement, and description has not been done beyond creating minimal box lists. The arrangement and description of materials, particularly those in this series, may change in the future as iterative processing occurs. Researchers are encouraged to document their citations with this in mind.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The papers of Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse's father, fundamentalist Presbyterian minister Donald Grey Barnhouse are located in the archives of the Presbyterian Historical Society (RG 480).
Researchers interested in Sylvia Plath should also review the Sylvia Plath collection at Smith College Special Collections (MRBC.MS.00045).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers of this clergywoman and psychotherapist reflect both her personal and professional life. Viewed as conservative in Boston/Cambridge and wildly radical in Dallas, these papers provide valuable insight into the spiritual journey of a woman within the structure of the Christian church. Contains personal and professional papers from 1915-96 related to her work as an Episcopal priest and psychotherapist, including correspondence, printed material, video and audio cassette tapes, photographs, memorabilia, manuscripts, writings, and speeches.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that she owned copyright, Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse assigned the copyright in her works in this collection to Smith College; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required.

For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. In particular, the estate of Sylvia Plath has retained copyright in works created by Plath.
Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with use.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: As a preservation measure, researchers must use digital copies of audiovisual materials in this collection. Please consult with Special Collections staff to request the creation of and access to digital copies.

did.unittitle: Correspondence from Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse's family and friends during her teen years

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: According to correspondence from Dorothy G. Barnhouse, she acquired the materials in January 2008 from Ruth's son, Chris Beuscher, who had received them from his brother, Will Beuscher, who had, in turn, retrieved them from the basement of their brother Bob's house where Ruth Barnhouse lived for a short time before her death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, much of it from her parents, and a small amount of other material from Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse's teen years, which she saved in a box for her entire life. The series also contains one folder of printoffs of family history, rememberances about Ruth, and context for these materials written by her sister, Dorothy G. Barnhouse.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The materials in this series were received from Ruth Barnhouse's sister, Dorothy G. Barnhouse, in 2008. They are accession 2017-S-0006.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials in this series have not been arranged in any particular order, however, it is unknown if they have remained in the order in which they were received in the archives.

did.unittitle: Files and clippings regarding Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of four folders of materials, mostly correspondence, kept by Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse about Sylvia Plath. The files document attempts, successful and unsuccessful, by numerous Plath biographers to interview Barnhouse about her famous former patient. The correspondence documents a shift in her attitude from the early 1970s, when she "steadfastly refused to talk to anyone by Harriet" (Rosenstein), to 1990 when she wrote to Rosenstein that she received many inquiries but "my memory has faded considerably" and she asked for Rosenstein to return Plath's letters to her so that she could be "as factual as possible" when speaking of Plath.
Also included are a small number of clippings Barnhouse collected about Plath from 1998, when Ted Hughes' book Birthay Letters was published.

These are the entirety of the known materials about Plath in boxes of Barnhouse's records sent to Smith College in 1999 and 2000. They have been screened and temporarily separated out from the rest of the accessions for ease of reference and access.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files about Plath remain organized as Barnhouse sent them to Smith College; the loose clippings have been put in a single folder.

did.unittitle: Sylvia Plath letters to Ruth Beuscher (later Ruth Barnhouse)

physdesc.extent: (14 items in one half-width letter size document box)

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: These letters were received in 2018 from Harriet Rosenstein, who had obtained them from Barnhouse during the course of her research into Sylvia Plath.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that Sylvia Plath held copyrights in these materials, that copyright has been retained by the Plath estate.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: These letters have been digitized, and the digital copies can be provided to remote researchers upon request.
The letters have been published in the second volume of The Letters of Sylvia Plath (2018).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of 14 letters written by Sylvia Plath to her former therapist, Ruth Beuscher (later known as Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse), while living in London. The letters date from February 1960 to February 1963, and are of a highly personal nature. In them, Plath discusses her life, including difficulties in her marriage to poet Ted Hughes, and seeks Beuscher/Barnhouse's advice.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dr. Ruth Beuscher (as Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse was then known) and Sylvia Plath met in 1953, when Beuscher treated Plath during her hospitalization at McLean Hospital following Plath's first suicide attempt. Plath continued private therapy with Dr. Beuscher in person through 1959, and continued a relationship that, by Barnhouse's later accounts, crossed lines between friendship and therapy by letter until Plath's death from suicide in 1963. Although Barnhouse destroyed Plath's earlier letters to her, she retained these from the last few years of Plath's life.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Effective September 6, 2018, these letters are open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: A few of Ruth Barnhouse's letters to Sylvia Plath may be found in the Sylvia Plath papers in the Mortimer Rare Book Collection.

did.unittitle: Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse personal and professional papers

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The contents of this series were received in the first accession of materials given to the Sophia Smith Collection by Ruth Barnhouse (accession 1999-S-0014), which was received shortly before her death in 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials from accession 1999-S-0040 that have been screened for confidential patient and pastoral information, and so are open to research. The remainder of the accession, which has not yet been reviewed by an archivist, is described in Series 5, Subseries 1.

This materials in this series were acquired directly from Ruth Barnhouse shortly before her death, and comprise a record of her careers as a Jungian psychotherapist, Episcopal priest, professor of theology, writer, and public speaker, as well as her personal and professional relationships.

This series includes some biographical information, materials related to an unpublished book on Christian ethics, and approximately half of her alphabetical correspondence files (A through Me). For most of her professional life, Barnhouse employed an administrative assistant who typed much of her correspondence and maintained these correspondence files. Barnhouse's correspondences, and the files, make very few distinctions between people for whom she served as a psychoanalyst, personal friends, and professional colleagues. It was not uncommon for someone to begin their relationship with Barnhouse in one of these categories and traverse all of them over the course of a years-long relationship. Many of her correspondents were members of the Episcopal or Catholic churches with whom she discussed topics ranging from the politics of professional organizations, to her personal and professional lives, to questions of spirituality, religion, and the occult. Of particular interest to researchers may be her discussion and defense of the ideas in her 1978 book Homosexuality: A Symbolic Confusion with sympathetic friends and like-minded colleagues, as well as her discussions of her career and struggles as one of the first women to be ordained as a priest in the Episcopal church.

This series also contains 185 audio recordings, many of them consisting of multiple audiocassette tapes. Most of the recordings appear to be of talks, lectures, and sermons that Barnhouse gave in a variety of settings, although a few of them are recordings of astrological readings Barnhouse had done for herself or others.

The audio recordings were organized and cataloged, and many of them transcribed, by Barnhouse's assistants. However, all that remains today of that work is the tapes themselves and the numbering system, which employs a two-letter abbreviation: SP, PR, OP, MF, S, FP, J, P, or PW. The key to that encoding, as well as most of the transcripts, were lost before they reached the archives. A few transcripts remain in the unprocessed portions of the accession.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The materials in this series have been closely reviewed by an archivist, and any items that were found to contain information about psychotherapy patients, people Barnhouse saw for professional pastoral counseling, and her academic students have been removed or redacted.

It appears that many of Barnhouse's close friends valued her insights and advice, both personal and spiritual, but correspondence has only been removed when it is clear that it was the product of an ongoing professional psychotherapueutic, pastoral, or professorial relationship. It is possible, even likely, that correspondence remains from people who Barnhouse first knew as patients, but with whom she developed long-term personal relationships. Since no exhaustive list of Barnhouse's patients exist, these individuals are currently impossible to identify.

When an entire file of correspondence fell into one of these categories, the file was destroyed and no record of it has been retained, in order to protect the correspondent's privacy. When a single piece of correspondence contained confidential information (for example, discussing a patient in the course of seeking a referral from a colleague), that piece of correspondence was redacted if possible or destroyed, and that fact is noted in a processing note in the finding aid.

In the 1990s, Barnhouse or her administrative assistant appears to have begun re-using paper to print off file copies of word processed correspondence. It was not uncommon for them to use the backs of Barnhouse's daily schedules, containing patient names, for this purpose. Whenever this was found, the correspondence was photocopied onto clean paper and the original destroyed.

Similarly, Barnhouse or her administrative assistant re-used office file folders, and after several decades some, but not all, of the layers of labels have fallen off of many of the folders. If a folder label had fallen off to reveal a second name, the folder was replaced during processing since it was impossible to determine the nature of Barnhouse's relationship with the person whose name was newly revealed.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files in this series remain arranged in the order in which they were received in the archives.

scopecontent.p: Like Barnhouse, Turnbull, also an Episcopal priest, was deeply involved in debates within the Episcopal church about homosexuality. The correspondence in this file is frequently, though not exclusively, on this topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence to and from Barnhouse on various subjects related to homosexuality and the church. Some is written by people who read Barnhouse's work; earlier correspondence includes her drafts and comments about writing her most widely read pieces on the topic, as well as letters with church leaders regarding a candidate for the priesthood whom Barnhouse alleged had made advances toward and "felt up" her sons. The file also includes Barnhouse's notes on the December 1969 AAAS meetings, which do not appear to have anything related to homosexuality.

Unprocessed accessions of Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse personal and professional materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of three unprocessed accessions of materials received from Ruth Barnhouse and her estate between 1999 and 2000.

The materials relate to Barnhouse's personal life, as well as to her careers in psychotherapy and the ministry. All known materials related to Sylvia Plath have been removed from this series and added to Series 2 for ease of access.

Materials from accession 1999-S-0014 that have been processed have been moved to Series 4. Note that box numbers repeat between accessions; boxes are being renumbered sequentially as they are processed.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for use under the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections, except that it must be thoroughly reviewed by an archivist for confidential patient and ministerial information prior to access.
This series is being processed on demand; please contact Smith College Special Collections to request that a portion be processed for your use.

did.unittitle: Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse personal and professional materials

accessrestrict.p: Reports, evaluations on candidates for ordination is marked, "CONFIDENTIAL."

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: As a preservation measure, researchers must use digital copies of audiovisual materials in this collection. Please consult with Special Collections staff to request the creation of and access to digital copies.
